thread.title: Many Australians try and hide their financial stresses
thread.title_full: Many Australians try and hide their financial stresses

author: Sophie Elsworth MoneysaverHQ deputy editor
title: Many Australians try and hide their financial stresses
text:
BOTTLING up financial stress is not uncommon particularly because many of us would prefer not to talk about it.
But tackling niggling monetary worries head-on is the best way to get on top of your finances.
New Galaxy Research shows the majority of Australians (73 per cent) feel anxious about their financial situation and almost half (43 per cent) admit they find it uncomfortable to talk about money.
Eqeus financial planner Gareth Colgan says Australians too often have the “she’ll be right attitude” and many need to implement financial goals into their lives.
“What are people actually trying to achieve in their life?,” he questions. “We like to see clients commit to their goals and we monitor their progress.’’
“We find that by putting these plans in place, there are goals that are important to them.
“They feel they are in control of their lives and this means they are less stressed.”
He says a simple case of working out your household income and weekly expenditure will get you well on your way to a happier financial future.
The ‘She’ll be right attitude’ does not serve us well ... Eqeus financial planner Gareth Colgan. Source: istock
The biggest barrier to improving your financial outlook is an attitude of burying your head in the sand, the research shows, because most of your money is being sucked up by bills and other living costs.
Simply starting a savings plan can help you remove any monetary stress says MoneySmart’s senior executive leader Miles Larbey.
“Pay yourself first — get savings deducted from your pay/benefits automatically. Most people don’t miss what they don’t see,’’ he said.
“Keep a separate savings account ... add in your windfalls, try to save any pay rises, bonuses or tax refunds.”
He also urges people to take charge of their regular costs including utility and phone bills by marking on the calendar when they are due.
Add up how much your big bills cost in total for the year and put aside an amount to cover these expenses when each pay cheque arrives, he adds.
Results by comparison website Finder show one of the most common financial worries — mortgage stress — is prominent among those whose repayments exceed 30 per cent of their monthly earnings.
People who buy property with a family member or friend are most likely to experience mortgage stress, with an average of 35 per cent of their income being used towards mortgage repayments.
